body.header: Was your first week what you expected? Why? Why not?
body.text: The first week wasn't too surprising for me. Meeting on the first day was interesting, it was strange to be in a classroom or school-like environment with much older students (including me) than the last time I was in school.

body.header: What are you struggling with?
body.text: Well, for the this assignment in particular I managed to tunnel on one slide and forget to check the others for assignments. I have also missed a standup purely due to my own negligence. These types of logistical struggles are common for me, so I will just need to stay on full alert for the duration of the prework. Once the in-person work begins, I expect to have less problems in that area.

body.header: What are you excited or eager to learn more about?
body.text: I'm excited to get more into javascript, node, react, etc. The logical elements behind webpages are way more interesting to me than the visual ones.

body.header: What are your thoughts on Pseudo Coding?
body.text: I enjoyed writing the pseudocode. The line between pseudocode and actual code was not clear to me - something like a for loop seemed like a specific feature of specific languages, so I wasn't sure if that was something I could use in pseudocode.

body.header: What are you struggling with?
body.text: I am not struggling with anything, particularly.

body.header: What are you excited or eager to learn more about?
body.text: I'm still excited about getting into javascript, and server-side web development.

body.header: What are your thoughts about the roles HTML, CSS, and Javascript play in the process of rendering content and providing user experience?
body.text: Hmm, that reads an awful lot like a test question... The answer that you're probably looking for is that HTML provides the structure for a web page, CSS makes it readable for humans, and Javascript makes it interactive.

body.header: What was one thing you liked and disliked about each of the new topics covered in Prework?
body.text:
I'm not too sure which topics you're referring to, but if its HTML/CSS/Javascript:
I liked understanding more of the interaction between HTML and CSS. I still don't like the actual design process, involving adding css and then visually checking the page, changing the css again, etc.
I really enjoyed working with javascript. Writing code that's simple and does the job is extremely satisfying. I didn't dislike anything about it. Though I am told that once I learn other languages I will have things to complain about with javascript.

body.header: What was helpful?
body.text: Justin and Ian were quite helpful! When I asked a question on slack, they responded within the minute.

body.header: What hindered your progress?
body.text: I can't think of anything external that really hindered me. Wow classic, perhaps.

body.header: How did you overcome challenges?
body.text: Blind persistence.

body.header: What did you learn about that helped you understand more about Design?
body.text: The talk on CRAP design principles was enlightening. One of my takeaways was the importance of whitespace.

body.header: What do you want to continue learning about that helps you understand Design better?
body.text: Learning and talking about graphic design was fun, but I would love to learn more about design in general, not just specifically graphic design.

body.header: What Design aspects are important to you as a user and as a developer?
body.text: I appreciate the concepts of Design that were talked about this week for how practical they were - they really took into account the actual purpose of what's being designed. I guess the most critical aspect of design to me is to keep the main thing the main thing.

body.header: What did you learn about that helped you understand the Development process?
body.text: I learned that I need to focus more on pseudocode. I find it hard to continue writing things when I don't even know if they'll work. I want to get in and test them before moving on, and before you know it I've written most of the code and only a few words of pseudocode. Obviously this will only work with small projects, so I need to get acclimated to writing out whole projects in pseudocode before touching actual code.

body.header: What does it mean to develop good code?
body.text:
Seems like good code needs to:
  • Be functional. Fulfill the need of the project.
  • Be maintainable. It should to be written to be easily upgradeable and readable.
These are in order of importance. There's no point in writing well-documented, well-commented code if it doesn't actually fulfill the need it's engineered for.

body.header: What does it mean to be a good Developer?
body.text: I certainly don't know the answer to that, but one important quality seems to be the ability to absorb and quickly utilize new information.

body.header: Why do you see Javascript useful or hard to use?
body.text: The upside of javascript seems to be that it runs on anything that can run a web browser.

body.header: What aspects about Javascript are you interested in learning more about?
body.text: Considering it's more or less my first language, I'm interested to learn more of everything about it.

body.header: Why do you see Javascript Frameworks and Libraries useful or hard to use?
body.text: I'm going to have to delay my answer for this one, since we haven't actually learned any yet.

body.header: What Frameworks or Libraries are you interested in learning more about?
body.text: React, considering we start that next week.

body.header: Why are CLIs scary?
body.text: I have a fair bit of experience with CLIs, so I don't find them scary. I think they're scary up until the point you learn basic directory movement: ls,cd,cd .., etc.

body.header: Would you build a CLI?  What would it do?
body.text: I'm not sure if this applies, but I really appreciate the simplicity of a script that takes command line arguments. I've made quite a few of those.
